G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant because Defendant is organized under the laws of Massachusetts and/or regularly conducts business within the Commonwealth, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 8, and rela.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 8, and related provisions, because the cause of action arose in Norfolk County, at the Premises located at 123 Main Street, Quincy, MA 02169.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the owner or occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors “a duty of reasonable care under all of the circumstances.” Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a unified standard of reasonable care to all lawful entrants. The quoted passage is from a concurrence discussing the treatment of trespassers, but the majority at page 708 expressly states that landowners/occupiers owe a duty of reasonable care under all the circumstances to lawful visitors. Thus the case directly supports the proposition as to “all lawful visitors,” even though it leaves trespasser status for separate treatment.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees should no longer be controlling in actions of tort for negligence, and that the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care under all of the circumstances.” (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).)

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: That duty includes an obligation to use reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to remedy or warn of conditions posing an unreasonable risk of harm that the owner knows or should know about.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the general premises-liability duty that the proposition paraphrases. The court explains that owners or possessors of land owe lawful visitors a common-law duty of reasonable care, specifically including an obligation to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers the owner knows or should know about. Although the case ultimately finds no duty regarding alterations to the adjacent state highway, its articulation of the landowner’s basic duty to maintain and warn is fully consistent with the claimed proposition.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988). Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (1988). Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349, 351 (1985).”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: That duty includes an obligation to use reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to remedy or warn of conditions posing an unreasonable risk of harm that the owner knows or should know about.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that, abandoning the natural/unnatural snow and ice distinction, property owners owe lawful visitors the same general premises-liability duty: to use reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect against dangerous conditions the owner knows or should know about. The court analogizes snow and ice hazards to other conditions like banana peels and rusted railings, confirming an obligation to remedy or protect against such risks rather than merely to avoid creating them.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Defendant, as a restaurant operator open to the public, had a specific duty to maintain walkways, aisles, and hallways in a reasonably safe condition for patrons, and to inspect those areas at reasonable intervals, to promptly clean up spills, and to warn invitees of hazards.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the defendant’s duty to customers to keep the premises reasonably safe, and explains that when a dangerous condition arises without the defendant’s fault, the law allows only a reasonable opportunity to become informed of it and to remedy or warn. The opinion then applies this by focusing on how long the spill existed and the opportunity for discovery, implicitly requiring reasonable inspection and prompt cleanup or warning. Although it ultimately finds no negligence on the facts, it clearly affirms the duty described in the proposition.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action… it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.raw_text: Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.proposition: Defendant, as a restaurant operator open to the public, had a specific duty to maintain walkways, aisles, and hallways in a reasonably safe condition for patrons, and to inspect those areas at reasonable intervals, to promptly clean up spills, and to warn invitees of hazards.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises used by patrons: to use due care to keep those premises in a reasonably safe condition or warn of dangers the owner knows or should know about. Although the defendant here is a transit authority rather than a restaurant, the articulated rule applies to business premises open to the public and encompasses maintaining and inspecting walkways/stairways for hazards such as foreign substances. The case is thus sound authority for the general duty described in the proposition, even though it does not detail inspection intervals.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. Rossley v. S. S. Kresge Co. 339 Mass. 654, 656. Coates v. First Natl. Stores Inc. 322 Mass. 563, 565. Vance v. Gould, 355 Mass. 104, 105.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–84 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a premises owner or occupier is negligent when it knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property and fails to take reasonable steps to remedy or warn against the condition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recites and endorses the traditional Massachusetts premises-liability rule that an owner is liable where it has actual or constructive notice of a dangerous condition and fails to use reasonable care to protect invitees. Although the court then adopts the mode-of-operation refinement for self-service stores, it repeatedly characterizes this as a modification of, not a departure from, the general rule that negligence turns on knowledge (actual or reasonably should know) of a dangerous condition plus failure to take reasonable remedial steps. Thus the case supports the stated general proposition about Massachusetts law.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” … This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition. Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955).

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 562–64 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a premises owner or occupier is negligent when it knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property and fails to take reasonable steps to remedy or warn against the condition.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the premises owner’s duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for customers, clarifies that the owner is not an insurer, and explains that liability arises when a dangerous condition exists for a time such that the owner, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of it and remedied it. The court affirms that the plaintiff’s recovery depends on whether the defendant, using reasonable care, should have known of and removed the foreign substance, thereby directly supporting the proposition about constructive notice and failure to take reasonable remedial or warning steps.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance. … We said in White v. Mugar, 280 Mass. 73, at page 75, ‘The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it.’”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy or warn of the wet and slippery hallway constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care owed to Plaintiff under Massachusetts common law and the Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343, 343A, as applied in Massachusetts.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.support_reasoning: The case does discuss Massachusetts common-law premises liability and Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A, and it affirms that a landowner may have a duty to remedy open and obvious dangers under certain circumstances. However, it does not involve or analyze a wet and slippery hallway, nor does it specifically hold that a failure to remedy or warn of such a hallway is a breach of duty. The opinion instead concerns a trampoline–pool setup and focuses on duty to remedy, not an independent duty to warn, so using it to support the hallway-specific proposition is an overextension.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… However, ‘[l]andowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises…’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting… Restatement (Second) of Torts, supra at § 343A comment f.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: The type of harm suffered by Plaintiff—slip‑and‑fall injury to the knee on a wet, unmarked tile floor—is a foreseeable result of Defendant’s failure to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of known hazards.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The case concerns negligent storage of firearms and the foreseeability that a violent, mentally unstable person with unsupervised access to a home might steal a gun and shoot someone. It does not address premises liability, slippery floors, or slip‑and‑fall injuries, nor does it discuss a landowner’s duty to maintain floors in a reasonably safe condition or to warn of wet surfaces. Therefore it does not support a proposition about the foreseeability of a knee injury from slipping on a wet, unmarked tile floor.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 638–40 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The type of harm suffered by Plaintiff—slip‑and‑fall injury to the knee on a wet, unmarked tile floor—is a foreseeable result of Defendant’s failure to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of known hazards.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: This concurrence explicitly states that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the slip‑and‑fall knee injury was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s failure to maintain safe premises and warn of hazards. Thus, this case is being cited for a proposition it does not support and in fact contradicts.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 85.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all of these damages under Massachusetts law.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all of these damages under Massachusetts law.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the measure and types of damages recoverable under Massachusetts law for specific landlord-tenant claims (breach of warranty of habitability, emotional distress under Chapter 93A) but it does not state a general principle that a plaintiff is entitled to recover “fair and reasonable compensation for all of these damages.” Instead, it applies particular statutory and common-law damage measures, including treble damages under c. 93A, and a specific formula for habitability damages. The broad, generic proposition about fair and reasonable compensation for all damages is not articulated or adopted as such in this case.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.relevant_excerpt: “The judge applied the correct measure of damages. Cases discussing the measure of damages for breach of the common law warranty of habitability hold that the tenant's damages are to be measured by the difference between the value of the dwelling as warranted (the agreed rent may be used as some evidence of this value) and the value of the dwelling unit as it exists in its defective condition.”

Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.raw_text: Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603, 613 (1981)
Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all of these damages under Massachusetts law.
Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with comparative negligence, loss of consortium, statutory presumptions of liability for vehicle owners, and appellate timing. It does not articulate a general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover ‘fair and reasonable compensation for all of these damages’ under Massachusetts law, nor does it discuss the measure of damages in that broad way. Any references to damages are case-specific (jury amounts, comparative reduction), not a statement of the general damages standard claimed in the proposition.
Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.relevant_excerpt: The evidence produced by the plaintiffs at the hearing indicated that the jury had determined Anne Feltch’s damages to be $117,000, and had reduced the consortium verdict by 37.5 per cent. Thus, the judge should have allowed the plaintiffs’ motion to correct the verdict. We conclude that there should be a correction of the consortium verdict upward to $117,000 without a further hearing.

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: In any event, under Massachusetts comparative negligence law, any negligence attributed to Plaintiff that is not greater than that of Defendant would only proportionally reduce Plaintiff’s recovery and would not bar it.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute and explains that in negligence actions a plaintiff’s contributory negligence only bars recovery if it is greater than the negligence of the defendants and otherwise merely reduces damages proportionally. The court contrasts this with the absolute bar that applies in warranty under Correia, making clear that under G.L. c. 231, § 85, negligence up to and including 50% does not bar recovery but diminishes it. That matches the proposition stated.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff his costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable law;
